pageContext.title: Go-Jekâ€™s Crystal Widjaja on her reading list, data stack, and tips for learning data analytics
pageContext.content:
This Q&A is edited from our AMA session with Crystal Widjaja, SVP of business intelligence and growth at Go-Jek.

Data science is arguably more popular, trending, and sought after. What made you become more invested in business intelligence in comparison to data science? â€”Â Marcel Christianis

Data science is absolutely a trendy and sexy job right now, and it can be used to solve a lot of very difficult problems. However, I personally love business intelligence because itâ€™s a little bit closer to the day-to-day business operations. I love designing data structures and architecture that work for a lot of different business units and revolutionize how people make decisions.

If Iâ€™d like to learn data analytics, what do you think are the first steps that I should take?Â â€”Â Krisna Adi Nugroho

Learning about data and statistics:

  • Andrew Ngâ€™s blog/various courses
  • The Data Warehouse Toolkit: The Definitive Guide to Dimensional ModelingÂ by Ralph Kimball and Margy Ross
  • Dataclysm: Love, Sex, Race, and Identityâ€“What Our Online Lives Tell Us about Our Offline SelvesÂ by Christian Rudder
  • How Not to Be Wrong: The Power of Mathematical ThinkingÂ by Jordan Ellenberg
  • Data Smart: Using Data Science to Transform Information into InsightÂ by John W. Foreman
  • Public Transit Should Be Uberâ€™s New Best Friend by Nate Silver
  • Why Uber Is an Economistâ€™s Dream by Stephen J. Dubner
  • The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Failâ€”But Some Donâ€™t by Nate Silver

Learning to code:

  • RegexOne
  • Learn Python the Hard Way: A Very Simple Introduction to the Terrifyingly Beautiful World of Computers and CodeÂ by Zed Shaw
  • DataCamp for SQL
  • Coursera for R

Thereâ€™s so much data out there to collect and analyze. How do you keep up with the massive amount of incoming data, prioritize which data point to focus on, and translate that to a decision-making asset? â€” Yukiko Hime

Yes, there is a mountain of data out there! We prioritize based on our OKRs for the quarter, ensuring that the results of what we decide to analyze will definitely influence a strategic decisionâ€”regardless of whether the results are positive or negative.

Whatâ€™s your daily routine? â€”Â Anthony Loekita Harsono

I am very structured with my daily routines!

  • 6 am to 7 am: Read. This can be books, articles (those that I saved throughout the day or those people sent me), or the news. Right now Iâ€™m reading Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind by Professor Yuval Noah Harari.
  • 7 am to 7:30 am: Gym
  • 8:30 am: Go to work!

Our days always start with standups, both the development and business teams. From there, it varies based on the day of the week. On Mondays, we do retrospectives on the previous weekâ€™s metrics and prioritize the next weekâ€™s growth experiments.

In business intelligence, we iterate on our analytics narratives and tech spikes while continuously improving the time-to-delivery and quality of data to product teams.

May I know the data stack that Go-Jek uses?Â â€”Â Anthony Loekita Harsono

We are primarily on Google Cloud Platform services. Iâ€™ve done a few talks on why we made this choice, but in essence theyâ€™ve built extremely scalable infrastructure and services that allow us to focus on data modeling and delivering insights.

What are the methodologies that Go-Jek uses? â€”Â Satria Budiman Tandyono

Every team at Go-Jek uses what is best for them! I can talk a little about the business intelligence/growth/performance marketing methodologies.

We run agile Kanban workflows so that business is always prioritized accordingly. We have many different data modeling techniques depending on the use case, but most business teams will actually use our denormalized tables in BigQuery rather than star/snowflake schemas, but for our RDBMs data, weâ€™re more likely to follow star schemas.

Snowflake schemas would complicate our queries given how multi-dimensional our businesses are.

Whatâ€™s your reading list?Â â€”Â Satria Budiman Tandyono

My reading list is quite long but hereâ€™s a few:

  • Astrophysics for People in a HurryÂ by Neil deGrasse Tyson
  • Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American CityÂ by Matthew Desmond
  • Homo DeusÂ by Yuval Noah Harari
  • Never Split the Difference: Negotiating As If Your Life Depended On ItÂ by Chris Voss
  • Managing HumansÂ by Michael Lopp
  • High Output ManagementÂ by Andrew Grove
  • The Mythical Man-Month: Essays on Software EngineeringÂ by Fred Brooks
  • The Hard Thing About Hard ThingsÂ by Ben Horowitz

How can data science contribute to a new startup?Â â€”Â Wahyu Budi Saputra

I would actually say that data science is not mission-critical for most startups. Data science has the most predictive power and application when you have large data sets, which most startups frankly will not have.

In the early years of Go-Jek, the role and vision of data started very early. We started small and ensured that we were exceptionally involved in the product development from the get go. Just ensure that there is a working feedback loop between data teams and other parts of the company, such as finance, product owners, and marketing, and it should happen as early as possible.

Because the bigger a company is, the harder it is to integrate effectively, or at all. If you have proper data sets, data science can come later. Solve the easy problems first.Â ğŸ™‚

Make sure that data is structured properly first. Having vast amounts of unstructured data is a sign that the business intelligence team and a product development team were not coordinating early enough, and data was stored in a â€œjust store itâ€ manner rather than having been methodologically curated and discussed for future use.

Audio, chat logs, and images, while relatively unstructured, should have some level of organizational design and cataloguing so that data scienceâ€™s AI and ML can make use of it quickly with as little data preprocessing as possible.

What was your experience like when weighing your options in US vs moving back to Indonesia to join Go-Jek? If you could go back in time, is there anything you would change and why? â€”Â Edo Setiaprasojo

My personal core value is centered around a love of learning. I truly felt that I could learn more by moving back to Indonesia and working at Go-Jek given the potential for growth, the level of ambition in the region, and peopleâ€™s willingness to transfer knowledge and lift others in the community.

If I could go back in time, I would have chosen to live closer to work and avoid the monstrous traffic sooner!

seo.description: Crystal is SVP of business intelligence and growth at the Indonesian ride-hailing giant.
